subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Aesthetic Concerns for a new font.
msgSnippet: Dear Kyudosha: This sounds great.  Do you plan to include the capability of producing the half-letters as Jerome can?  I believe this is an important
messageBody:
Dear Kyudosha:

This sounds great.  Do you plan to include the capability of producing the half-letters as Jerome can?  I believe this is an important characteristic of Senior Quikscript (Readscript).  

I have some questions about your e-mail.  Can you be more explicit regarding your ideas regarding a keyboard layout for your font.  You made reference to the sounds of TO, but TO does not have sounds (phonemes), English has sounds.  I think of TO as a set of symbols that, unfortunately, poorly represent the sounds of English.  There are approximately 44 English phonemes, and our keyboards are limited to 26 letters.  Thus, it almost seems inevitable that some QS characters will involve two key strokes rather than one.  Do you have an alternative to this?

Anyone else out there that can offer any thoughts on Kyudosha's project?

Paige

kyudosha wrote:
Hello all.  I am designing a replacement truetype font for Jerome.
This new font (called KINGSLEY.TTF) will include (among other things)
a more intuitive keyboard layout based on a one-to-one conversion
between the sounds of T.O. and Readscript, characters with standard
stroke widths and joining points, and kerning pairs that provide what
I perceive to be the best representation of the way Readscript was
meant to be written.

For consistency's sake, I am currently going to be the only active
developer until the font reaches a suitable beta release state, but I
would like the input and participation of all Readscript enthusiasts
in this endeavor, such that we can truely have a font written
by-enthusiasts-for-enthusiasts and one that we can all have some
amount of personal involvement and satisfaction in.

There are, of course, stumbling blocks to be overcome and questions
about standardization that need to be asked, so I have decided to ask
them here and now (even though the characters are only about halfway
finished).

To kick things off, my first question to the quickscript community
regards the joining of characters to letter #25/Roe.

As is plainly seen, the character was designed with two joining
points, both of which are incoming points and exist on the same
x-plane.  It shares the first of these properties with #22/May, and
shares both of these properties with only one other character:
#37/OUt. This introduces problems in font design when being connected
to by any characters that cross into the x-plane through or beyond
both joining sites (i.e. #'s 3, 7, 10, 14, 26, 27).  When examined
further, however, one notes that most of these characters would NEVER
join to #25, except perhaps #7 or #27.  I have noticed on page 13 of
the Quickscript Manual that there seemes to be an extra character #36
in the example "mere" (27-36-25).  Is this really #36, or one of the
"confusing linking strokes" that Read talks about?  If it IS #36, is
this because of English pronunciation?

Thanks, and I look forward to further input in participation in this
project
